Title: If $\int_{\mathbb R^2} \frac{\vert f(x)-f(y)\vert}{\vert x-y\vert^2}dxdy<+\infty$ then $f$ is a.e. constant
Content:
Let $f \in L^1(\mathbb R)$. If 
  $$
\int_\mathbb R \int_\mathbb R \frac{\vert f(x)-f(y)\vert}{\vert x-y\vert^2}dxdy<+\infty
$$
  then $f$ is a.e. constant. I do not know how to begin. I thought that we are set if we show that the integrand is bounded a.e. (the function $f$ would be 2-holderian, hence constant)  but this is not true in general. I mean $\phi \in L^1(\mathbb R)$ does not imply $\phi \in L^{\infty}(\mathbb R)$. Would you please give me some useful hints in order to start? Thanks.
